question: Question_05_(c)
statement:
Define a sequence \emph{x}\textsubscript{0}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
... by the initial conditions \emph{x}\textsubscript{0} = \emph{a},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1} = \emph{b} and \emph{x}\textsubscript{2} =
\emph{c} together with the recursion relation

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n\end{align*}

for \emph{n} = 0, 1, 2, ...

\textbf{(c)} Explain how you could ensure that the \emph{a}, \emph{b}
and \emph{c} you find in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_05_(b)}{part
(b)} are real numbers.
sols:
For real matrices, just as complex eigenvalues, also complex
eigenvectors come in conjugate pairs. Hence

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
v_2 = \overline{v_3}\end{align*}

Hence \emph{v\textsubscript{2} + v\textsubscript{3}} is a real vector
and therefore we ensure that the solution vector \emph{{[}c, b, a{]}T}
in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_05_(b)}{part
(b)} is real by choosing real coefficients \emph{s} and \emph{t} and
setting \emph{s = t}:

\begin{align*}\left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = s (v_2 + v_3) \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{R}\right\}\end{align*}
hints:
For a real matrix, if $\displaystyle v$ is an eigenvector to a complex
eigenvalue $\displaystyle \lambda$, then $\displaystyle \overline v$ is
an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue $\displaystyle \overline \lambda$
